It is quite a somber experience much like going to the Pearl Harbor Arizona memorial, a bit depressing because this prison is hwere the Japanese housed political prisoners during its occupation of Korea.   but history holds pleasant and difficult memories. This is one of the somber ones. But once you visit here you can hike your boots off by heading uphill to find the remaining route of the wall around Seoul liking up with the Bukhansan national Park route - that was a tremendous full day hike around the outskirts of Seoul.

title: Chilling prison complex
text: Never being in trouble with the law, visiting a prison is always a thing of novelty, a cool and fun thing to with friends.Once inside we are guided in a series of displays explaining various chapters about the prison itself. Its construction, expansion and recent shutdown. Dispersed in various building of the complex we soon get to see the real prison wards, the old facilities where people got locked in, get questioned and even tortured. In the outdoor areas we get to see the deathrow housing and the nowayback tunnel beside of it... Chilling! All in all, this museum shows the cruel reality on this particular prison in it's different eras and managements where koreans had been imprisioned until recent past.Eye openning experience!

title: Definitely worth a trip
text: Having visited Seoul 4 times over the past few years, and visiting only the beautiful touristy places, this trip we decided to visit the Seodaemun Prison History Hall to learn more about Korea's history.  Most of the things are rather self explanatory and there are English explanations at some places to tell you more about the story behind. Its an eye opening experience for the family and myself. We got to see the cell where the Korean activist were kept in, the torture chambers, the clothing the prisons wore, execution hall, etc. At the end of the visit, you may leave the place feeling quite disturbed due to the sound effects played and the things you see. Nevertheless, i would still recommend to everyone who visits Seoul to pay a visit to this place.

title: Definitely worth your time
text: There are a few buildings for visitors to explore. Each building has interesting things to see and you get to learn how hard it was for the prisoners who were imprisoned there. They had replicas of torture equipment displayed - fingernail removal, crate with inward facing nails, a vertical movement-restricting coffin-like box. The walk through the prison cells is also rather chilling as there're life-sized mannequins of prison guards staring down at you while you walk along the corridors. Look into some of the cells, and you can see (mannequins of) prisoners crouched and wailing. There was one zone that was off-limits to photography as it was where the executions took place. I don't know why, but as I walked into the room, my heart dropped and I felt like crying. It's a very informative museum and it's worth visiting even if you don't understand Korean.

title: Different side to Seoul
text: We've been to korea several times and every trip was filled with lots of shopping, beautiful scenery, great food and lots of fun. This time however we decided to learn a little more about Korea's history and decided to visit Seodaemun Prison History Hall. Adult tickets are 1500 Won per person, about a dollar fifty (USD$1.50). Very informative with english explanations and easy to navigate around. Very interesting, sad and an eye opening experience. We got to see the cells that kept the korean independence activists, the torture rooms, the different torture methods used against the koreans, the different prison buildings etc. I recommend this place for everyone that is planning a trip to Seoul. Get to see and experience a different part of the beautiful vibrant city and learn a little more about the country. This place brings chills to the spine, especially when in the execution grounds and theres a tree called the "Wailing Tree". It is said that prisoners grabbed that tree before being dragged to the execution grounds with regrets of not succeeding with their independence campaigns/activities. A side note, we went in Summer and it's EXTREMELY hot in korea. The place is not air conditioned so it will be rather stuffy. Bring a hand held fan. To get there, you can take the subway to Dongnimmun Station (Subway Line 3), Exit 5. We took a taxi there and they will drop you off at the Independence Park. Walk all the way to the back of the park and you will see the Prison. About 200m walk.

title: A must-see for any visitor to Seoul
text: This museum was extremely well done.  It tells a very interesting and chilling part of Korea's history.  Before travelling to Korea, I knew very little about Korea's history prior to the Korea war.  This museum focuses on the early part of the 20th century when Korea was occupied by Japanese forces.  The prison was used to house revolutionaries fighting for Korea's independence.  The museum starts a little slow, but as you continue, you get to walk through buildings and facilities that were actually used at that time (some are replicas).  It is really frightening to hear when went on in those buildings in the not so distant past and a very moving experience to be standing in them when you learn about it.  The entire experience was quite emotional, but extremely eye-opening and well worth the the time to visit.  I highly recommend it for any visitor to Seoul.

title: A must see when in Seoul
text: This prison was built in the early 1900s by the Japanese and is kept as a historical reminder of what happened to Koreans during this time. It is a very sad, eye opening museum. Walking through the prison and seeing the cells where people were tourtured was a harrowing experience. The prison is very cheap to enter- only a few thousand won, and you can look around at your own pace- either with or without headphones.  If you go in winter, be sure to wrap up extra warm- it was colder inside the old prison than out!

title: Worth a visit if you have time
text: Worth a visit though off the beaten track a bit ( though that's a good thing often enough). Explanations are in English and it's well laid out and easy to navigate the buildings. Recommended if you want to learn more about recent Korean history though I wouldn't bring the kids as the place tells quite a harrowing story.

title: Seodaemun Prison is a Good Reminder of History
text: I almost did not go to this prison since it was a little out of the way for me. But I had already seen all the wonderful palaces in Seoul and decided to take my family here. Wow! Glad I did. The prison was built in 1908 and is a vivid reminder of Japanese cruelty to the Koreans by the Japanese during their many years of occupation and subjugation of Korea. There are photographs documenting the cruelty and you can even go into cells where the Koreans were held. My kids learned an important lesson about war, torture and cruelty of one people by another and hopefully they will remember this when they grow up and become leaders in their own lives. My son opined, "it's hard to believe how low humans can go." he is right. This prison is a good learning experience and should be on your list of places to visit just as the European concentration camps are a terrible reminders.

title: Important and intresting
text: Seodaemun prison history hall tells a very important story about the korean history. It is a scary place in a beautiful place. The museum has been restored with great thought and humbleness. This is not a place somone is making money on, the entrance fee is just symbolic and there¬¥s no souvenir shop. There are some vending machines with drinks for the same price as outside. I would definetely recommend a visit.

title: Seodaemun, Not for Children
text: Seodaemun Prison is a sad and brutal reminder of the 35 year long colonial rule of Korea by Japan. This issue still resonates today becase Japan and Korea often cannot carry out basic diplomacy between each other. Japan has apologized on multiple occassions, but many Koreans feel the sincerity is lacking. While Japanese right-ring politicians (and sometimes Prime Ministers) flame the fires in Korea by claiming the "comfort women" issue is not true, or by visiting the Yasukuni Shrine which honors some Imperial era war criminals. I will not delve into the current politics, but Seodamun Prison does reflect a thorn in relations that even today is not easily resolved. Most Japanese buildings in Korea were torched or demolished the days following Japan's defeat in World War II. Indeed, nearly 1,000 Shinto shrines in Korea became bonfires as celebrations swept the country. Korean's feeling resentment for the years of bowing to shinto shrines, being banned from speaking Korean, and the forced adoption of Japanese names were finally free to unleash their rage. In 1996, with much fanfare one of the last symbols of Japan's colonial rule (the Government General Building) was destroyed on live television. Japan had offered to pay for the buildings restoration or removal cost and transportation to Japan, Korea refused and the demolition began. Seodaemun survived in large part, because its use as a prison continued all the way until 1987! There are few places left in Korea where you can see and explore Japanese colonial buildings, the Gunsan port area perhaps being the best preserved district.Seodamun Prison Hall is worth visiting, but I must warn there are gruesome diplays of torture. In Korea some school groups visit the site, but I must disagree wholeheartedly that young children be allowed here. Children below middle school cannot understand how or why this happened. For those who think the displays do not reflect the real history, please feel free to research.

title: Prison insights
text: This museum gives an overview of prison facilities prior to 1910. Torture methods and instruments are on display. Interesting but not to exciting...

title: If you have spare time, fit this place in
text: It's not in my top few places to visit but if you have say approx 5 days in SK then you can fit this place in. It's quite large and inexpensive to visit. It informs of the horrible torture the Japanese gave the Koreans and some other historical information about SK.

title: Very sobering experience
text: It was very informative and well laid out.  It tells a very sobering and thought provoking history of the prison and the main reason why it was built.  It certainly makes you count your blessings.

title: Humbling, educational experience
text: Although small and sparse, this attraction tries its best to tell the history of how the Japanese used this prison to suppress Korean revolutionaries and uprisings.It shows the ways the Japanese tortured and interrogated prisoners - can be rather frightening. It also allows visitors to enter a prison cell to show the size of it. You can also visit the execution ground.It is definitely educational and gives visitors a short lesson on modern Korean history.

title: Amazing History Experience
text: Great place to learn about how the Japanese occupied Korean in the early 1900's. As well as how prisoners were treated a that time. It's fairly large and tickets are cheap. There is even a place to see some of the torture devices used on prisoners.If you go in winter, I recommend dressing VERY warm! There is no heating.

title: Very good place to learn
text: It is located near the subway, Dongnimun Station, exit 5. Go out from exit 5 and it's on your left-hand side. The fee is 1,500 Won.It was a prison during japanese colonialization. In the Exhibition Hall you can read the history of the site. In one part of the building, they place all thousands of the prisoners during that time on the wall and it fills all 3 walls. You can see and place yourself inside the jails. But you can not enter nor take picture in the execution building. You can only see it from outside.There's toilets and vending machines in the complex. The site is very clean as other sites I visited in Seoul.The Independence Park, Independence Gate and Independence Hall are nearby. When you exit the prison complex, go to your right-hand side and just walk ahead. You can spend at least 1 hour here since there are several buildings open for public. But if you need to save time, you can jump straight from the Exhibition Building to the Execution Building. But you're going to miss good parts.

title: worthwhile stop...
text: This is a great place to visit for a piece of Korean independance history. It was built to house anti-colonial activists back in 1907 and was over populated as most of these prisons were worldwide. Now it houses a museum and memorial to all those that suffered within its walls. You get to read about what occured and how bad it was during those times. There are also artifacts from the past and you can enter the cells or chambers to feel what the political prisoners went through.Its located within the Independance Park and as an overall package a must see while visiting Seoul. It might not be a common choice for most but its worth at times to go off the beaten track.

title: Definitely worhtwhile, but beware the schoolchildren
text: This was a most unique and interesting hisorical site.  This prison has been brilliantly restored to better convey the atrocities committed during Japanese occupation of Korea.  Although this should be a quiet, even solemn visit, the noise level of the many school groups made the visit frustrating at times.  The children had very little supervision and were running around and yelling.  Many of the displays depict the various types of torture inflicted upon the prisoners.  I'm not even sure that school aged children should be looking at this type of thing.  Nonetheless, this site is very informative and so historically important it should be visited.
